page.title: 06Buildings of Mow Cop.
page.content: On the upper parts of Mow Cop all around the, summit, there is a large village with a population of several thousand. The border between Staffordshire and Cheshire runs through the centre of the village. The Staffordshire part of Mow Cop has grown gradually from the 13th or 14th century, with houses being built in an uncontrolled way.This has lead to a sprawling village with old stone cottages,between which have been built modern brick houses.The only large scale recent building is a council estate of 56 houses built by Newcastle council after the second world war.Most of the houses on the Cheshire side were built on a rectangular pattern.Most of these are terraced cottages and have more in common with the miners villages at the foot of Mow Cop than with the buildings on the Staffordshire side.
